DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: SILVESTRE, F. J.;Flávio J. Silvestre;Flavio J. Silvestre;SILVESTRE, FLAVIO;SILVESTRE, FLÁVIO;SILVESTRE, FLAVIO J.;SILVESTRE, FLÁVIO J.;SILVESTRE, FLÁVIO J;SILVESTRE, FLÁVIO JOSÉ;JOSÉ SILVESTRE, FLÁVIO

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduação em Engenharia Aeronáutica pelo Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica (2004), mestrado em Engenharia Aeronautica e Mecânica pelo Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica (2007) e doutorado em Luft- und Raumfahrt pela Technische Universität Berlin (2012). Atualmente é professor titular (Departamento de Mecânica de Voo, Controle do Voo e Aeroelasticidade) do Institut für Luft- und Raumfahrt da Technische Universität Berlin, e professor colaborador do Programa de Pós-Graduação em Engenharia Aeronáutica e Mecânica do Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica. Tem experiência na área de Engenharia Aeronáutica, com ênfase em Mecânica do Voo, Controle e Aeroelasticidade. Atua principalmente nos seguintes temas: dinâmica e controle de aeronaves flexíveis, aeroservoelasticidade, ensaio em voo aeroelástico, controle de escoamento.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Ciência Sem Fronteiras - Projeto de Pesquisador Visitante Especial - Reduced-order modelling of installed turbulent jets and their sound radiation
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This project will aim to provide a concrete step forward in terms of our understanding of the mechanisms of sound generation in propulsive turbulent jets, in both installed and uninstalled confgurations. The following objectives will be pursued: clarify the physics of sound source mechanisms in the absence of the aircraft architecture, clarify the physics of the additional sound source mechanisms that result when the jet is installed on the aircraft: interaction with aircraft architecture, generate new understanding with respect to the sensitivity of jet noise to both upstream and externally-imposed perturbations, develop reduced-complexity modelling frameworks by which jets and their noise can be modelled in installed and uninstalled configurations, provide a framework for the implementation of real-time, model-based and model-free, closed-loop control using sensors located on the aircraft fuselage and wing.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Ciência Sem Fronteiras - Projeto de Pesquisador Visitante Especial - Reduced-order modelling of installed turbulent jets and their sound radiation

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Royal Academy of Engineering - Newton Research Collaboration Programme - Development of a Fast Computational Tool for Highly Flexible Flight Dynamics
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The aerospace industry worldwide is seeking to develop ?green aircraft? which are cleaner, quieter and more efficient, based on demands for reduction of fuel burn, emission of pollutants and costs of operation. This has motivated studies into new aircraft designs and configurations by leading aircraft manufacturers such as Airbus, Boeing and Embraer. Most of these futuristic designs involve a higher level of structural flexibility than in conventional aircraft. Even currently, the trends in the aviation industry are to increase wing length (to reduce induced drag) and maximise use of composites, which lead to increased structural flexibility. Flexible aircraft structures result in the aeroelastic behaviour becoming closer in frequency to that of the flight dynamics. Current procedures for flight control laws which are based on decoupling between flight dynamics (rigid-body) and aeroelastic dynamics, are thus not valid for flexible aircraft. A combined formulation of aeroelasticity and flight dynamics, using Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) for aerodynamics and Finite Element Method (FEM) for structural dynamics is an expensive problem, requiring several hours of computational time even with High Performance Computing (HPC) resources. This project proposes to develop a low-order model for the combined flight dynamics and aeroelastic simulation of flexible aircraft. The collaboration is unique because the University of Glasgow has expertise in low-order aerodynamics modelling, and ITA has expertise in flight physics, thereby bringing together the competence to solve a challenging problem. The work programme will involve one visit by a researcher from each partner institution to the other, for a period of 3 months each. The research carried out will be published through 2 journal articles, and the main achievements will be disseminated in the IFASD 2017 conference. This project will enable the researchers to work with aircraft industry from both countries, and to pursue further sources of funding.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: FAPESP & The UK Academies/CONFAP - Fellowship and Research Mobility - Modelling and Control for Next-Generation Flexible Aircraft
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This research application addresses the fundamental challenge to employ high fidelity simulations of flow around flexible aircraft on a routine basis enhancing dynamic load predictions used for structural sizing of aircraft components. The ambition of the actual cooperation is to deliver a software tool that empowers innovative algorithms to reduce costs while retaining accuracy, underpinning a leap change in today?s environment: (a) high fidelity simulations are yet too expensive despite the increasing computer power; (b) the predictive capability of such simulations is not fully exploited, being used in the late stages of aircraft programmes; (c) dynamic load cases are currently neglected to simplify the loading scenarios; and (d) aircraft control law design is still based on the rigid-body approximation, leading to aeroservoelastic issues.
The proposed research project addresses some of the unique aeroelastic challenges presented by next- generation aircraft. It tackles, specifically, the need for detailed characterisation of geometric and flow nonlinearities by developing rapid yet accurate computational models. The project will contribute to scientific knowledge and novel techniques in instrumentation, computational and experimental aeroelasticity applicable not only in aeronautics but also in wind energy. The project will act as a catalyst for the development of technologies underpinning the robust design of more efficient aerial configurations. Finally, the project will also result in the generation of a wealth of experimental nonlinear aeroelastic benchmark data not currently available.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: DinaFlex: Estudos Avançados em Física do Vôo ? Fase 2
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Investigar uma nova tratativa para o desenvolvimento de leis de controle, que dispensam o processo de filtragem/desacoplamento da resposta aeroelástica (notch-filters) e empregam outras fontes de informações a respeito da dinâmica aeroelástica.
Prosseguir nos estudos de efeitos de flexibilidade estrutural na dinâmica de aeronaves, agregando mais valor ao conhecimento transferido para a Embraer no projeto anterior (referência Projeto GDT0067-14, ?Estudos Avançados em Física do Vôo?).

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: PIPE/FAPESP - Desenvolvimento e Demonstração em Voo de Aeronave Leve Elétrica com Sistema de Piloto Automático de Baixo Custo
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Os trabalhos de pesquisa ora propostos contemplam a otimização estrutural final da plataforma de testes, visando máxima performance (mínimo peso), bem como ajustes no seu projeto mecânico para a adequada acomodação dos componentes associados ao piloto automático. Extensa atividade de preparação à fabricação (processos, ferramentais, etc.) será executada pela CENIC, com o emprego de técnicas de gestão e controle de qualidade de produto aeronáutico adequadas a uma futura certificação na categoria Aeronave Leve Esportiva (ALE) ? mercado em expansão no Brasil. Sob o ponto de vista eletroeletrônico, será conduzido o desenvolvimento do subsistema de PA, utilizando?se componentes miniaturizados de VANT largamente disponíveis, aos quais algoritmos de guiamento e controle dedicados serão incorporados. Métodos de engenharia consagrados, empregados usualmente pela CENIC Aeronáutica/Engenharia em diversos projetos aeroespaciais, serão aplicados em todas as atividades. Ao final, espera?se manufaturar, integrar e ensaiar em voo um protótipo da aeronave.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Estudos Avançados em Física do Voo
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Este projeto de pesquisa é dedicado à construção de uma aeronave flexível para servir como plataforma de ensaios em voo para:
- desenvolvimento e validação de modelos da dinâmica de voo de aeronaves flexíveis desenvolvidos por pesquisadores do ITA;
- determinação do limiar para a utilização de modelos com simplificações de pequenos deslocamentos aeroelásticos;
- investigação do acoplamento inercial entre a os graus de liberdade de corpo rígido e elásticos para manobras com grande deslocamento estruturais;
- desenvolvimento e validação de sistema de controle de voo para a atenuação do acoplamento entre os modos de corpo rígido e os modos elásticos.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Future Combat Aircraft Design Study and Demonstration, FADEMO
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The objective of this project is the development of a scaled fighter that will serve to test
different technologies for the future combat aircraft design. This project will serve to bring
different groups together to contribute with different subprojects. It will provide an
opportunity to further develop subscale prototyping and flight test capability. This planning
project will result in preparation and instrumentation of an existing demonstrator (Generic
Future Fighter, GFF at LiU) for a subscale flight test mission. The result shall lead to the
definition of a larger project that would continue to the end of 2016, the GFF2, considering
additionally: (i) aeroelastic and dynamic scaling; (ii) prototype with variable (relaxed) static
margin; (iii) SAS implementation to fly in a relaxed stability configuration; (iv) model
identification on the basis of flight test data.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Systematic energy management for flight with electric propulsion to conserve resources (STELAR)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
STELAR is a project planned for four years from 2020/21 for the development of an automatic flight control system for energy-optimised flight under consideration of atmospheric conditions as part of the Aeronautical Research Programme (LUFO VI).
It is planned to create a modular simulation environment based on models of the aerodynamics and propulsion system. This simulation environment will be used to develop a model-based, energyoptimized and thus resource-saving control system for general aviation.
Together with a planned cockpit interface development at the TU-Berlin and a planned hardware-in-the-loop flight simulation test the system shall be validated.
Funded by the German Ministry of Economy and Energy, BMWi, Luftfahrtforschungsprogramm VI.1.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: MODULAR-TUB ? Model-based Software-Development for digital intelligent Flight Control Systems
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
MODULAR-TUB is a partner project at TU Berlin as part of the joint research project MODULAR (Smart Actuator Concepts for electromechanical und electro-hydraulic Drives). MODULAR aims to develop innovative concepts for smart electromechanical and electro-hydraulic actuators. It is funded by the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWi) as part of its Federal Aviation Research Programme (LUFO VI-1). The planned project duration is 39 months (01.01.2020 ? 31.03.2023). The joint research project is led by Liebherr-Aerospace Lindenberg GmbH.
Objectives:
The joint research project MODULAR aims to develop innovative concepts for smart electromechanical and electro-hydraulic actuators. Research topics include more efficient methods for system design, new approaches in system monitoring and constructive solutions and control principles for electromechanical and electro-hydraulic actuators.

TU Berlin?s partner project MODULAR-TUB contributes by developing new monitoring mechanisms for next-generation flight control systems and work on efficient, model-based development processes of flight control software towards goal 4 (system capability) of the Federal Aviation Research Programme, as an understanding of the interaction of individual sub-systems (actuators, sensors, on-board computers) and the overall system ?aircraft? are required. Mechanisms for the detection of Common Mode Failures contribute towards goal 2 (safe and passenger-friendly aviation).

The scientific and technical goals are:

1. Requirements written in natural language are converted in a formal manner into executable specification models. These models are used to check the consistency and completeness of requirements in simulations and to define test cases and expected values. This allows an earlier verification of requirements in the development process (front loading). The models that are generated in the development process are reused, as functional models during design, for virtual integration, and as design models for generating source code.

2. Currently flight control systems of commercial aircraft do not include dissimilar monitoring functions that detect Common Mode Failures. New approaches based on observer methods are developed based on independent specifications. This contributes to increased dissimilarity of safety-critical functions in accordance with new EASA guidelines.
Funded by the German Ministry of Economy and Energy, BMWi, Luftfahrtforschungsprogramm VI.1.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Analysis and evaluation methods for automatic, continuous flap operation and simulation (INTELWI-TUB)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Within the cooperative project INTELWI (Intelligent Wing Design and Verification), an "intelligent wing" for future commercial aircraft is being investigated, which reacts automatically to external influences such as manoeuvres and gusts with load reduction. Such an "intelligent" wing is a consequent next step in the development of future commercial aircraft. It should make a significant contribution to ensuring the future competitiveness of Airbus as an aircraft manufacturer. The project is based on several existing research results on the sensor, control and actuator technology for wings and brings them together in an overall design.

The project INTELWI-TUB (Analysis and Evaluation Methods for Automatic Continuous Flap Driving and Simulation) at the Technical University of Berlin contributes to the development of more powerful and efficient aircraft in cooperation with the industrial partner's Airbus and Liebherr. At the TU Berlin, a function for an automatic, continuously moving slat/flap system (ACMSFS) for an intelligent wing is being developed so that the aircraft can be operated at its current optimum point with minimum aerodynamic drag during flight phases close to the airport. Flying at the optimum point leads to a reduction in emissions and fuel. The developed ACMSFS function is evaluated in flight simulator studies using criteria for flight performance, flight characteristics, economy and eco-efficiency. The existing design and evaluation methods will be extended and refined in the course of the studies, validated using current and future operational flight procedures and optimised by pilot comments. The studies enable the rapid development and evaluation of new high-lift system variants in the future. The ability to evaluate such variants in an operational context also addresses the overall system capability.
Funded by the German Ministry of Economy and Energy, BMWi, Luftfahrtforschungsprogramm VI.1.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Concept for an aircraft preliminary design tool with flight mechanical evaluation capability (TUBCADO)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Currently used semi-empirical methods in preliminary aircraft design are no longer accurate enough for the flight mechanics assessment of aircraft with novel wing and control surface concepts. Effects of parameter variations in the design on flight performance, flight characteristics, loads and system masses cannot be sufficiently investigated. Therefore, high-fidelity design and evaluation methods are needed for the preliminary design phase.
FMRA develops in the project TUBCADO a "Concept for a preliminary design tool with flight-mechanical evaluation capability", which will contribute to the development of new aircraft designs with the university partners in the UNICADO (University Conceptual Aircraft Design and Optimization) network. The aim of FMRA in TUBCADO is to develop modules that can be used for the flight mechanical design and evaluation of wing and empennage concepts. These modules shall be integrated into the aircraft preliminary design environment UNICADO, shown in Figure 1.

For TUBCADO, FMRA develops the UNICADO modules: "Wing Design" and "Empennage Sizing". The module for component design (wing and tail) shall be developed in such a way that dimensioning variables result from relevant CS-25 criteria regarding flight property requirements (static and dynamic stability, controllability, etc.) and flight performance requirements (take-off, landing, etc.).
Funded by the German Ministry of Economy and Energy, BMWi, Luftfahrtforschungsprogramm VI.1.
